justification: The authors note that "a cognitive approach offers more direct measures of mental effort ... such as neuroimaging, pupillometry, or dual-task paradigms."
Mental effort is said to be measurable with "pupillometry" as one of the direct methods listed for assessing this construct.
Dual-task paradigms are explicitly grouped with neuroimaging and pupillometry as "direct measures of mental effort."
The paper describes how some studies "measure speed and accuracy then claim that these measures are proxies for mental effort."
The authors recommend that "direct measures of working memory exist, such as pupillometry and behavioral manipulations," linking pupillometry to working-memory demand.
In the same sentence, "behavioral manipulations" are given as another direct way to measure working-memory demand in visualization tasks.
Reporting on Hegarty et al., the article states that salient features "drew viewers' attention (as measured by eye fixations)", indicating eye-tracking data as the measurement of attention.
